bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, April 29, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests copies of Cuban newspaper articles, about the work of the Yellow Fever Commission, and for maps of the Rojas farm and the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, April 29, 1940
div1.opener:
Yellow fever.
April 29, 1940
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
The two weeks since my return have been rather hectic. I found my desk cluttered
with work waiting for me, we had a large medical meeting here and I had a house guest
visiting us, and on top of that, our nine-year old boy developed acute appendicitis and
was operated upon. But all is well that ends well, and he is getting along fine, now
being back home.

I did appreciate your long and thorough revision of my questionnaire, but after
all, it was Mrs. Phillips' job to do that, and I am sorry you went to so much trouble.
If the occasion should arise again, please have it done in her office, and have her send
me the bill.

I am sending you a number of snapshots which you wanted and if you want any more
of them, I shall be delighted to send them to you. I am very much chagrined at the way
one roll turned out. At the end of each film roll there is a sticker, to stick the roll
shut. Apparently, one of these stickers tore off and got caught in the back of the
camera, unbeknown to me. It stuck out just far enough to ruin each exposure on one film
and it happened to be the film I was using in Marianao. Incidentally, your picture at
General Lee's headquarters is therefore ruined, but I am going to make a separate list
and ask you to have the young photographer take four or five more photographs more for
me, including that one.

And now for some special items:
(1) I am returning your check, as I think there will be some expenses which you
and Mr. Pogolotti will be under in my behalf, and I think it best, if you don't mind, for
you to have a little money available.
(2) At your leisure, would you some time write me a couple of paragraphs on the
distinction between Camp Columbia and Columbia Barracks. I understand the site was the
same place but the one was erected by the Americans and the other by the Cubans.
(3) I don't know whether to ask you or Miss Cabrera to do the following but at
least I will mention it to you, as you might be very interested anyhow. I am anxious to
see what the Cuban papers said on certain occasions. For example, according to Kelly's
book and otherwise, on or about November 21, 1900, one of the Cuban papers poured forth
considerable criticism on Reed for proposing human experiments. On December 23, 1900,
a banquet was given to Finlay and to Reed. I should certainly like to see what was said
and the reaction of the people to the idea. On February 6, 1900, Major Reed gave his
medical talk before the Pan-American Congress in Havana. You remember what Carroll is
supposed to have said about that occasion. I have also seen mentioned comments by Carroll
and Reed referring to the Havana Post of November 24 and 25, 1900, and January 31, 1901.
I wonder if sometime you would have time to go to the Bibliotece de la Socieded Economica
Dragones between Royal and San Nicolas, and perhaps look over the papers La Marina la
Lucca for those dates. If you find anything interesting, sometimes a library will make
a photostatic copy of certain items rather inexpensively. If not, you could dictate
something to Mrs. Phillips at my expense.
(4) I have not yet got any old maps of Camp Columbia. I am going to write to
Washington and also to Dr. Ramos before bothering you further about this.
(5) Please hold the pieces of the tree for me. I have written to Washington
to find out whether I can bring them into our country, although I believe you were
Mr. John J. Moran
- 2 -
April 29, 1940
going to give one piece to the wood carver in Havana, next to the restaurant, Paris
Cafe, to see what he could do about it.
(6) Do you have any idea where I could get ahold of a tree expert in
Havana who could certify as to the approximate age of the Framboyant tree at the
Cuban Camp Lazear, and also the one by the shacks on the San Jose farm. If you could
make some inquiries, perhaps to the Department of Agriculture in Cuba, I should
appreciate knowing what his advice would cost. But perhaps when I get my report for
Dr. Ramos, it would not be inappropriate for me to suggest that he have the ages of
the trees identified by one of their government experts.
(7) I am writing Mr. Pew somewhat along the lines you suggested.
(8) I have not yet received the copies of the two maps of the Rojas farm
from Mr. Pogolotti but this may take a little time. Please pay him the expense out
of what I left with you.
(9) If the photographer has not yet taken a picture of the Lazear statue in
Finlay Park, to be taken just about 3 P.M.--not earlier and not much later--you can
hold this matter up until I send you in a few days, a list of the half dozen other
pictures to take. I want him to take three or four more pictures at the San Jose
farm and I will send you specific directions for them. I would also like to have
him take a picture of you before General Lee's headquarters but you will hear later
about this.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
